text: The Center for WorkLife Law ("WorkLife Law" or "WLL") is a non-partisan research and advocacy grouphttp://www.jeffschwartzlaw.com/2016/07/08/know- your-rights-if-you-are-breastfeeding-in-california/ housed at the University of California, Hastings College of the Law in San Francisco, California. WorkLife Law seeks to advance gender and racial equalityhttps://www.wsgr.com/WSGR/Display.aspx?SectionName=careers/diversity.htm at work and in higher educationhttp://www.slate.com/blogs/xx_factor/2016/03/07/universities_discriminate_against_pregnant_graduate_students_in_violation.html through practical initiatives. WLL staff advocate for changes in policieshttp://www.ssa.uchicago.edu/can-more-stable-work-schedules-help- employees-and-businesses-thrive that discriminate against women and people of color and create research-based, actionable tools for companies and individuals to use to address discriminationhttps://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2015/03/how-to- make-your-company-less-sexist-and-racist/388931/ in their workplaces and schools. WLL has many initiatives and programs to target different types of discrimination, including those focused on pregnancy,http://www.bwhi.org/events/2015/03/31/non-imperative-event/getting- help-at-work-the-employee-s-guide-to-pregnancy- accommodation/http://familyvaluesatwork.org/docs/Shop-Manual-FINAL-LPWF.pdf breast-feeding,http://www.huffingtonpost.com/joan-williams/pumping-milk- at-40000-fee_b_9909234.html and caregivinghttps://www.eeoc.gov/policy/docs/caregiving.html discrimination. WLL was founded in 1998 and is currently led by Joan C. Williams. ==References== Category:Advocacy groups in the United States Category:1998 establishments in California
